title.title: The Correspondence of John Hunt and Joshua Evans

msIdentifier.institution: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

projectDesc.p: The correspondence of Quaker ministers John Hunt and Joshua Evans are stored at the Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College. With the generous support of H. David and Joyce E. Hunt, Library staff scanned and transcribed these letters in 2023 and encoded the text in TEI. The 2023 project also included researching individuals mentioned in the text to create and update records about them in the Social Networks and Archival Context website

opener.dateline: Greenwich State of Connecticut, 28th of 6th month, 1794

div.p: although I am a stranger to thee, yet from the acquaintance I had with thy husband while in our parts I take the freedom to write to thee, having the request of thy husband therein. I may inform thee that I accompanied him from near New York through Connecticut and to the yearly meeting at Rhode Island, and was at diverse meeting on our way where the kind reception of his services and company amongst Friends and others where our lot was cast was comfortable to me. And I may say it hath been satisfactory to me that I have had the opportunity of bearing him company so far, as well as also when I parted with him to find that he was likely to have suitable company.

We parted on Rhode Island at the house of our friend Thomas Robinson the 18th of this month. He was then in good health and often admired that he had been so much favored therewith in his travels since he left home, considering the weak state he was in a little before he left set out. He then set forward for Bedford, expecting to take the meetings in his way thereto in company with Jacob Mott. From Bedford he expected to go to Nantucket Quarterly Meeting, and at his return a Friend that seemed very agreeable to him (as well as Friends) by the name of Thomas Roach expected to bear him company on the further part of his visit. I have not any doubt but it would be very agreeable to thee to know the sympathy he met with amongst his friends as well as their care in endeavoring to make him comfortable, which appeared far beyond what I can express. Therefore I hope thou may be as comfortable in his absence as possible for a person to be when thus separated from their dear companion.

closer.salute: This from thy friend although stranger,

address.addrLine: To Ann Evans, wife of Joshua Evans
To the care of William Savery
